Señor Donato works as a salaried driver and belongs to one of the drivers' unions in La Paz.  His wife works making women's skirts, which she sells at the a market that operates daily in the city of La Paz.

The loan will be for his wife's business, as she will use it to acquire at wholesale the fabric that is her raw material, so as to reduce her costs.

Donato and his wife live in their own home, which is located in the Obispo Bosque area of La Paz city.  They are married with three children.

loans.use: to buy fabric for making women's skirts.

loans.name: Katty Fernanda

texts.es:
Katty es una persona tranquila, trabajadora humilde y bondadosa que le gusta ser amigable, es casada y tiene dos hijos de 5 años y 1 mes de nacido. Vive con su familia en Tulcán que es la Capital de la Provincia del Carchi al Norte de Ecuador.

Katty trabaja sola en el comercio de artículos para fiestas, empezó con este negocio hace 5 años con una amiga pero actualmente Katty compró el otro 50% y ahora es dueña del 100% del negocio. Es el tercer crédito que solicita Fodemi el mismo que va a ser utilizado para surtir su negocio con muñecas, tarjetas, globos, piñatas y mas artículos de fiesta que le permita incrementar su negocio, esta inversión ayudará a Katty a solventar algunas necesidades que tienen en su casa y de la misma manera sacar adelante a sus hijos.

Su sueño es ver su negocio crecer, ayudar a más gente y sobretodo que a su familia no le falte el pan de cada día.
texts.en:
Katty is a tranquil, hardworking, humble and generous person who likes to be friendly.  She’s married and has two children; one of them is five years old and the other is a month old.  She lives with her family in Tulcán which is the capital of Carchi Province in northern Ecuador.

Katty works alone selling party supplies.  She started the business five years ago with a girlfriend but Katty has now bought up her 50% and now owns 100% of the business.  This is the third Fodemi loan that she will use to stock her business with dolls, greeting cards, balloons, piñatas and other party supplies to increase business.  This investment will help Katty solve some needs she has at home while at the same time raising her children.

Her dream is to see her business grow, to help more people and, above all, that her family not lack their daily bread.

loans.use: to buy party supplies.

loans.name: Dorjpagma

texts.en:
Mrs. Dorjpagma is widowed and a pensioner. She had worked as a merchant in a state organization for many years before she retired. Now she lives with one of her daughters and her nephew in her apartment which is located within the boundaries of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

Her apartment has become very old and uncomfortable to live in.  It was built about 40 years ago and all of its decoration and window insulation have disappeared now. Heat loss happens all the time in winter. Therefore, she decided to make the necessary adjustments to her apartment with hired workers.  With the loan, she will purchase some building materials to make the improvements to her apartment and to pay the salary for jobbers.

loans.use: To purchase some building materials to make improvements to her apartment and to pay the salary for jobbers.

loans.name: Dominga

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SAYHUA 3”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Urubamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Dominga; ella tiene 46 años de edad y es casada y tiene 4 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de chicha, choclos y golosinas, ella tiene un pequeño puesto en el mercado de Urubamba donde vende desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m, por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, el sueño de la socia es tener un local para que pueda vende chicha, choclos y golosinas. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar maíz al por mayor y también comprar golosinas como chupetes, caramelos, chicles y galletas al por mayor.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Dominga, 46, is a member of the “Sayhua 3” communal bank that’s located in Urubamba District belonging to Urubamba Province and Cusco Department.  

She is married and has four children.  She alternates her daily chores with a business selling chicha [corn-based drink], dehydrated potatoes and snacks.  She has a small stand in the market in Urubamba where she sells from 8am until 6pm; she supports her children with this business.  Her dream is to have a locale where she can sell chicha, dehydrated potatoes and snacks.  She’s asking for the loan to buy corn at wholesale and also snacks like lollipops, candy, chewing gum and cookies at wholesale.  She is happy about the loan and commits to make her installment payments.

loans.use: to buy corn at wholesale and also to buy snacks at wholesale.

loans.name: Santa Rosa Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formó gracias a una de las miembros, quien se acercó a la Fundación muy interesada en formar un grupo solidario porque en su barrio se había formado uno y quería intentar hacer que funcione. De allí surge el grupo llamado Santa Rosa, el cual está integrado por 13 mujeres muy trabajadoras y luchadoras.
La Sra. Margarita es Presidenta del comité y se dedica a la venta de artículos de mercería, comenta que su negocio es muy prospero, ya que tiene muchas ventas gracias a la buena cantidad de clientes que siemrpe se acercan a su negocio. Una de sus metas es poder seguir creciendo y de esa forma poder seguir ayudando en la manutención de la casa.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de prendas e vestir, zapatillas, calzados, artículos para regalos en general. Agradece a la fundación por la oportunidad de progreso que esta le da.
texts.en:
This committee was formed thanks to one of its members who approached the foundation.  She was very interested in forming a joint group because in her neighborhood one had formed and she wanted to try to make another one work.  From there arises the group called Santa Rosa, which is comprised of 13 hard-working and fighting women.

Margarita is the president of the committee and she sells haberdashery.  She says that her business is very prosperous due to the many sales thanks to the great number of customers who come to her business.  One of her goals is to be able to keep expanding and in that way be able to keep helping with the maintenance of the house.  

She requests the loan to buy clothing and apparel, shoes, footwear, and gift items in general.  She thanks the foundation for the opportunity of progress which it gives her.

loans.use: to buy clothing and apparel, shoes, footwear, and gift items in general.

loans.name: Chork

texts.en:
Chork, 68, is married and resides with his wife and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia. He and his wife have been involved in an agricultural business for over 20 years, and have extensive experience and are successful in their career. 

Two of his children are garment workers. Due to the factory being far away from home, Chork is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a motorbike for his children to commute to work. By doing so, his children can get to work on time and save some money from their transportation expenses to support the family. In the future, he would like to build a new concrete house and support his youngest child to higher studies.

loans.use: to purchase a motorbike for his children to commute to work.

loans.name: Mujeres Bendecidas 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
Altagracia is the coordinator of her group, Mujeres Bendecidas 1 & 2 (Blessed Women). She lives in a simple structure with her long-term partner and 6 children. She says that her most difficult challenge has been to establish her business, and now to be sustainable. In the meantime, she plans to continue enjoying her work.

Altagracia is excited to be taking her 3rd loan with Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business, where she sells plastic packaging, by buying some bags of spoons, forks, cups, plates and other plastic containers. She sells them as additional business.

Altagracia's group is located in the urban slums surrounding Santo Domingo. Altagracia, in one of the two pictures, is the one with a red and black shirt.  She is a very hard worker and enthusiastic woman.

loans.use: to buy plastic packaging

loans.name: Suliaman

texts.en:
This is 38 year-old Sulaiman. He is married and has no children, but has four dependents, who live with him to be fostered.  

In 2004, Sulaiman established a business; he sells soft drinks, tinned milk, sardines, luncheon meat, sugar, bread, batteries, eggs, etc. He began his business because his parents did not provide any formal education for him. He started selling liquor with a very small amount of money; the profit he accumulated was used to join his elder brother's used-clothing business. Later he used his profit to start his own business selling watches and transformed that into a grocery shop. Working seven days a week, 18 hours a day, he earns about 3,148,000 SLL every month from this business. 

He would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL. Sulaiman requires this loan to buy the following items: cartons of sardines, luncheon meat, batteries, Ovaltine, milk, bread, eggs, and bags of gari and sugar. In the future, Sulaiman plans to purchase a piece of land, provide quality education for his children, reinvest and expand his business. The loan will help him generate more income, as his major challenge is lack of adequate capital. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy sardines, luncheon meat, batteries, Ovaltine, milk, bread, eggs and bags of gari and sugar.

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en:
Elsa is a 29 years old resident of Quezon City, Philippines and a  member of Center of Community Transformation (CCT). While her husband, Jaime is at work, she is in charged of the household chores and also managing a Direct Selling business, where she sell personal products to her friends and neighbors like lotion, soap, makeup and such. She’s earning for about P8, 000 every month. 

Since there’s always an increase on the product price, revolving fund is what she wants to maintain. She always dreams of having her business expanded where she can have complete products to put on her display cabinet that will result on business increase.

Basically a customer will wait for a weeks just to have the product/s they ordered, however availability of products is one strategy to increase revenue. With this, Elsa applied for a Php 15, 000 loan for her to have revolving fund for the business. She's praying that CCT would approve the amount.

Despite of being busy managing the business, Elsa spares time attending CCT group fellowship that consist of 10-15 individuals where she can gain strength spiritually and where she hear testimonies from other CCT partners and able to hear God’s word, study the Word of God, build social relationship with other partners, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To have revolving fund for her direct selling business.

loans.name: Ocola

texts.en:
Ocola J. is 52 years old and is married with 5 children. He is Acholi and is one of the many thousands of people who were forced to flee their homes in the North because of the war that has been going on for the last 20 years. His family lives in an Internally Displaced People's camp in the outskirts of Kampala called the Acholi Quarter. Six months ago J. joined Life in Africa and has been an active member ever since. He started as a bracelet maker in the Invisible Children Bracelet Project but his hard work and determination quickly earned him a promotion to a sanding processor.

He has acquired a piece of land from the King of Buganda who has sympathy for the people of Acholi and who has set aside free land for them. Knowing that the people of the Acholi quarter have to go long distances to look for water, he has a plan to install a water tap on his land. The current water sellers who bring water in to this hilltop area are charging five shillings per litre for water which makes it very hard for the people to purchase water for their needs. With a water tap installed on his land, J. will be able to purchase water for only one shilling per litre and he plans on selling this water for a reduced rate of 3 shillings per litre to his community.

Not only will this provide a steady income for his family needs, but it will also offer a valuable service to his community at a more affordable price than they can currently get. This will insure that he has a secure source of buyers for his water, and it is likely to have a great impact on those living in the Acholi quarters.

To accomplish this project, J. is seeking a loan in the amount of shs. 800,000 ($475). He es-timates that once he acquires this loan it will take approximately one week to have the water tap installed. Below is his budget:

16 metal pipes @ 12000= each =192000=
connection fee to national water=300000=
labor charges & other expenses =200000=
building of small house so that the tap can be locked to avoid theft =100000=
The whole total is 792000=.

Based on his current income, J. will be able to repay this loan in 12 months. J. loves music and dance, and has designated the community impact portion of the interest he pays to support Life in Africa's Talent Discovery program.

loans.use: Installation of water tap & water company fees

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: EXPAND HER CHICKEN FARMING BUSINESS

loans.name: Ebi

texts.en: Mrs. Ebi S. had 6 months of training before she started up her business in the year 2004. She is 42 years old and married with three children. She requests a loan of USD 550 to expand her business.

loans.use: To improve on her business

loans.name: Ivonne

texts.es:
Ivonne is 50 years old and lives with her children who are students. She is also a secondary education teacher and is conscious of the need to prepare her children very well for the future.

Ivonne has a fast food and stationery business located inside a school. She started her business with $200 that she saved from her afternoon job. She takes care of the business in the mornings.

The loan she is asking for will be used to make suitable improvements inside the business. She has noticed that she needs to improve her business' image in order to increase the sales. Ivonne needs to buy another display case and improve and embellish the walls at her location.

She trusts that the business will give them the economic solvency to help her children in what they need most. She has a stable family and a lot of enthusiasm for work.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Ramirez-Gregg, Kiva Volunteer.

Descripción del Negocio

La Sra. Ivonne tiene un negocio de venta de comida rápida y de articulos de papeleria que atiende en las mañanas y esta ubicado dentro de una escuela. Dicho negocio lo emprendió con $200 que ahorro de su trabajo vespertino.

Uso del Préstamo

Ella utilizará el préstamo para realizar adecuaciones dentro de su local pues ha notado que es necesario mejorar la imagen del negocio. Para incrementar las ventas, necesIta comprar un vitrina mas y enlucir las paredes de su local.

Información Personal

Ivonne tiene 50 años. Sus hijos estudian. Su casa es de cemento y siendo ella maestra de educacion secundaria esta conciente de la necesidad de preparar bien a sus hijos para el futuro. Por ello confia que su negocio le dará la solvencia para ayudarlos en lo que más pueda. Tiene estabilidad familiar y mucho entusiasmo para trabajar.

loans.use: Improvements to her business.

loans.name: Maria Esthela

texts.es:
In Monterrey, Nuevo León lives Maria Esthela, married and more of two sons aged 6 and 15. In order to improve the quality of life of her family Maris began her own business by making and selling flour tortillas. Associating herself with a neighbor, she began with a few sales and little by little, through her the hard work and that of her associates, the business began to grow rapidly. Today she also sells cosmetics, with great results. Maria is a very hard working and patient worker, who likes to fight for her goals and the well being of her family is her greatest incentive.

Today Maria needs a loan of $200 which she promises to return in 3 months, which will be used to purchase inventory. The expansion of her store and the well being of her family is in your hands. If you decide to support Maris, her and her family would be very appreciate.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

En Monterrey, Nuevo León vive Maria Esthela, ella es casada y tiene dos hijos de 6 y 15 años de edad. Para mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia Maria inició su propio negocio con la elaboración y venta de tortillas de harina asociándose con unas vecinas, empezó con muy pocas ventas y poco a poco con el esfuerzo de ella y sus asociadas el negocio comenzó a crecer rápidamente, ahora también ha incorporado la venta de cosméticos, obteniendo muy buenos resultados. Maria es una mujer muy trabajadora y paciente, que le gusta luchar por lo que se propone y el bienestar de su familia es su más grande incentivo.

En estos momentos Maria necesita un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 200 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía y que se compromete a regresar en 3 meses. El crecimiento de este negocio y el bienestar de esta familia esta en tus manos, decídete a apoyar a Maria, ella y su familia te lo agradecerán.

loans.use: Increase inventory of the store

loans.name: Maria Miriam

texts.es:
Doña Miriam cooks traditional food in her home for her regular customers from the community. She is 56 years old and has one son. She belongs to the the Group Niño de Atocha 2 together with doña Yari Arellano Acuña, who sells cosmetic products from catalogues. With the loan doña Miriam will make adaptations to the places where she sells her meals and doña Yari will expand her business by selling hamburgers as well.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck, Kiva volunteer.

MIRIAM, ella se dedica a la preparación de comidas tradicionales en su casa , tiene 56 años y un hijo ,sus clientes habituales son las personas de su comunidad. Pertenece al Grupo Niño de Atocha 2 junto con doña Yari Arellano Acuña (venta de productos por catálogos de cosmetología). Con el préstamo Miriam adaptará mejor el lugar donde vende sus comidas y doña Yari ampliará su rubro vendiendo hamburguesas

loans.use: Extend sale of traditional food

loans.name: Ous

texts.en: Mrs. Ous S., age 43, works with her husband on their plot of farmland. They grow rice crops, together earning around US$5 a day. They have three children, two of whom are employed at a garment factory making about US$75 a month each, while their third child is unemployed. Mrs. S. would like to receive a loan of US$700 to purchase a small plot of land and seeds for cultivation. She hopes that, by expanding her output to meet customer demand, she will be able to earn more and raise the family’s standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase of land and seeds for cultivation

loans.name: Ramiz

texts.en: Ramiz lives in Khachmaz town. He was born in 1964. He is married, has 2 children. This man has sold dates and fruit for 2 years. He buys the dates from the villages for sale. Now he needs a loan of $950 to increase his goods and get more income.

loans.use: To buy dates and fruit

loans.name: Munaku B(Vi) Group

texts.en:
This group has been together for one year. Phiona is 30 years old, and she is a single mother of one child. She sells fruits and vegetables. She wants to use the extra profits to re-invest in the fruit business. Josephine, Jackline and Prossy all sell used clothes and want to use the loan to expand their businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits for sale.

loans.name: Bwase East C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Rose M.. She is currently in the business of operating a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to purchase a hair dryer. Rose is 21 years old and is single. Each week, Rose makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a better business premise. Rose has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to buy a hair dryer and the loan was paid back on time.

Rose is joined in her small group by Harriet K., Sowed N. and Robinah M.. Harriet K. has a business running a grocery store and wants to buy more groceries to sell. Sowed N. is currently operating a business milling maize and wants a loan to stock more maize. Robinah M. operates a business running a grocery store and wants to increase inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more salon equipment to widen customer base

loans.name: Nasma

texts.en:
Mambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania! This is Nasma N.. She is 30 years old, married, and has three children between the ages of 5 and 19 years old. In addition, she has two dependents living with her because their parents cannot afford to care for them. In 2006, Nasma established her clothing and cosmetics business. Working seven days a week, and 9 to 12 hours a day, she earns about $100 each month from her business. She is assisted by her sister and one employee. Nasma has already received and successfully repaid one loan from SELFINA, and now seeks a new loan in order to purchase additional stocks of clothes, shoes, and cosmetics. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profit by approximately $45. In the future, Nasma plans to diversify her business. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback micro-finance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are not considered to be credit-worthy by financial institutions because they lack tangible assets that can serve as collateral. As such, low income women in Tanzania typically receive poor financial support and in turn only limited access to basic needs and services.

Fortunately, SELFINA has been a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women in Tanzania. Simply put, SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women through an arrangement called a sale and leaseback transaction. More specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extends a loan to her to facilitate the transaction, and then leases the equipment back to her.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing additional clothing, shoes, and cosmetics.

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
Maria Luisa belongs to the Banco Comunal La Familia group, located in Jr Urubamba 798, in the district of Calleria, in the county of Ucayali. She is 52 years old and has 4 kids, he husband is a welder. With the first loan of $300 that Maria Luisa received from Manuela Ramos, she decided to invest in a small grocery store.

Now this small store has grown and she has a store which sells gas and has a small public telephone so that she can earn more and enjoy better finances. Her kids look after the store whilst she works.

With this loan of $2500, which she will repay over a period of 4 months, she will buy, 1 sack of rice, 1 sack of sugar, oil, fizzy drinks, carbon and some construction materials to sell gas.

Maria Luisa is very grateful that Manuela Ramos will help make her dreams come true: her store will grow and thanks to this her kids will be able to study.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

La señora Maria Luisa pertenece al Banco Comunal La Familia, ubicado en el Jr. Urubamba 798, del Distrito D. Calleria del Departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 52 años es madre D. 4 hijos, su esposo es soldador, Maria Luisa con el primer préstamo recibido D. Manuela Ramos S/. 300 decidió invertirlo en una pequeña bodega. En la actualidad su bodega ha crecido y esta implementando un local para venta D. gas y un teléfono publico para poder generar mas ingresos y gozar D. una buena economía, con la ayuda D. sus hijos atienD. su bodega mientras ella trabaja. Con este préstamo recibido D. S/ 2,500 el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará: 1 saco D. arroz, 1 saco D. azúcar, aceite, gaseosas, carbón y materiales D. construcción para su local D. venta D. gas. Maria Luisa esta muy agradecida con Manuela Ramos por hacer realidad sus sueños D. ver crecer su bodega, gracias a ello pueD. hacer estudiar a sus hijos.

loans.use: With the loan she will buy more merchandise to sell/Con el prestamo comprara mas mercaderia para su venta

loans.name: Trang Thị

texts.vi:
Chị Nguyễn Thị Trang, 42 tuổi, tham gia vào Quỹ năm 2002. Cả 4 người con của chị đều đang trong độ tuổi đến trường. Vốn vay của Quỹ được chị đầu tư chủ yếu vào chăn nuôi gia súc. Số lượng gia súc chăn nuôi tăng theo cùng mức vốn vay qua các năm. Tiền lãi thu được bình quân mỗi tháng từ chăn nuôi khoảng 200USD. Bên cạnh đó, anh Chuyên chồng chị làm thợ xây có thu nhập hàng ngày nên luôn hỗ trợ vợ trong việc hoàn trả. Từ mức vốn vay ban đầu 50USD, vòng vốn này chị Trang đã mạnh dạn vay 625USD để mua trâu bò về chăn nuôi.

Translated from Vietnamese by Chi N., Kiva Volunteer.

Ms. Trang Thi N., 42 years old, joined the fund in 2002. All four of her children are school-aged. The loan she obtained from the fund was used to invest mainly in raising cattle. The increase in the amount of cattle she raises each year varies with the loan amount she is able to obtain. The average revenue from the business is about 200 USD a month. In addition, her husband Chuyen works as a construction worker with a daily salary so he always assists her with the loan repayment. In contrast to the first loan of 50 USD, Ms. Trang is boldly requesting a loan of 625 USD in this funding round to buy cattle.

loans.use: Buy cattle

loans.name: Mahmudov

texts.ru:
A. Mahmudov is 48 years old and has 3 children. He has been in business for long time now. He sells women's shoes. After repaying his previous loan, he decided to borrow again in order to purchase more shoes. He is extremely thankful to KIVA for the support and understanding. He is certain that he will be able to repay the second loan in the same way as he did the first.

Translated from Russian by Jane Mazur, Kiva volunteer

Махмудов Азиз,мужчина в возросте 48 лет имеет 3 детей, бизнесмен со стажем.Имеет оборот по торговле женской обуви.Окончив займ он решил увеличить сумму займа для приобретения женской обуви. Он искренне благодарен KIVA за поддержку и понимание. Он уверен что сможет повторно без проблем погасить второй займ.

loans.use: Shoe sales

loans.name: Aissatou

texts.fr:
Aissatou N., whom everyone calls Fatou, is a young woman who was born in 1970 in Thies. She lives with her husband in the Parcelles Assainies district of Thies. After completing her housework, she shops at the local market for the ingredients to make incense, which she sells to her neighbors, her intended customers. She has requested this loan in order to increase her profit margin.

Translated from French by Joyce, Kiva Volunteer.

Aissatou dite Fatou N. est une jeune femme née en1970 à thies. Elle vit avec son mari au quartier des Parcelles Assainies de Thies. Apres les travaux ménagers, elle s'approvisionne sur le marché local de produits divers pour faire de l'encens qu'elle revend à ses voisines qui sont sa clientèle cible. C'est dans le but d'augmenter sa marge bénéficiaire qu'elle demande ce pret.

loans.use: Purchase of a variety of goods

loans.name: Maria Leticia

texts.es:
Leticia inició el negocio porqué el trabajo de su esposo no es constante y a veces falta dinero en su casa y ella quizó ayudarlo para asi mejorar sus condiciones de mi vida como familia ya que sus hijos están creciendo y uno de ellos ya va a la escuela, y cada día sus necesidades son mayores. Comenzódesde marzo de 1991, cuando todavía era estudiante, un día una amiga de su mamá le ofreció hacer una demostración en su casa de los productos que actualmente vende. Esa misma amiga le sugiro vender dichos productos, y de esta forma ella se ayudaba a costear su carrera. Fue así que empezó primero como vendedora y actualmente es coordinadora de un grupo de vendedoras y esta trabajando muy fuerte para llegar a ser directora.

Ella necesita un prestamo por US $500 que pagara en 5 meses para poder surtir los pedidos de mis clientas y que estas me sigan comprando cada vez y de esta manera aumentar mis ganancias.

loans.use: comprar mercancia

loans.name: Yen

texts.en: Yen N., 28, works growing vegetables in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Her farm is just enough to support her family members. Her husband, Nhem Nhoeun, 30, is a construction worker building houses. On average, he makes US$5 each day. Yen wants to have profit from her farm, so she decided to take out a loan of US$400 to purchase fertilizers and more seeds to grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and more seeds to grow.

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en:
Mabel Y. is married and has four children. She has received schooling through to Senior High education. Mabel sells groceries like sugar, rice, biscuits, soap and others at Kotokoraba, which is the heart of Cape Coast. She has been in this business since 1998. Mabel uses her income to help her husband in the payment of the children's school fees and other utility bills.

Mabel will use the loan to increase her capital to buy more groceries for sale, to meet her ever-increasing customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mabel plans to invest in her children's education.

loans.use: To increase her capital to buy more groceries for sale, to meet her ever-increasing customers.

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr: Mamadou D. est un commerçant agé de 25 ans  il est célibataire .son activité principale est la vente de produits de premiere necessité  sourtout des denrées alimentaires .Il est societaire de la caisse depuis 3 mois  .Avec le pret sollicite il renforce son activite par l achat de quantite importante de marchandises.
texts.en:
Mamadou D. is a businessman who is 25 years old. He is single. His primary activity is to sell basic goods, especially food. He is a member of the cooperative since 3 months ago. With the loan he will reinforce his activity by buying a large quantiity of merchandise.

Translated from French by Isabelle Barres, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Loan capital

loans.name: Manzura

texts.en: K. Manzura lives in Khujand. She is married and has 2 children. K. currently works in the commercial service and trade, and trades costume jewelry. Mrs. K. is currently requesting a loan to expand her business and improve her customer base. She hopes to use the profit earned to support her family and care for her children.

loans.use: To increase the range of her goods

loans.name: Martiza Lizet

texts.es:
La microempresaria Maritza Lizet Sáenz B. tiene 36 años de edad, es casada con 4 hijos, todos estudian en nivel primario y secundario. Desde hace más de 3 años esta señora se dedica a la venta de perfumes, cremas, colonias y otros productos de belleza que son utilizados por el sexo femenino.

Al igual que otras mujeres que se dedican a este tipo de actividad, Maritza ofrece sus productos con facilidades de pago a fin de hacer dicho productos mas accesible a su sector consumidor (en este caso las mujeres), las utilidades que genera este negocio es bastante atractivo, sin embargo por las facilidades de pago que ofrecen deben contar con un capital propio para poder enfrentar los pagos ya que también reciben estos productos al crédito pero con plazos relativamente cortos.

Por tal razón necesita que le financien para comprar los siguientes productos:

3 cremas humectantes a US$ 15 dólares cada una, 5 agua de colonia a US$ 05 dólares cada una, 5 mascarillas de proteína a US$ 04 dólares cada una, 3 perfumes Blams a US$ 20 dólares cada uno, 3 perfumes new blue a US$ 25 dólares cada uno y 3 perfumes Courd a US$ 25 dólares cada uno.
texts.en:
The micro-businesswoman Maritza Lizet Sáenz B. is 36 years old and married with four children. Her children are all studying in primary or secondary school. Maritza has worked for the past three years selling perfumes, creams, colognes and other beauty products for women. Similarly to other women who work in this field, Maritza offers her products for sale with a payment plan in order to make them more accessible to her customers. The income from this type of business is quite attractive, however because of the payment plan on offer the business owner requires their own capital to be able to make upfront payments. The business owner also receives the products on credit, but with a relatively short timeframe for repayment. For this reason Maritza is seeking a loan in order to purchase the following products: 3 moisturising creams costing US$15 each; 5 eau de cologne at US$5 each; 5 protein face masks at US$4 each; 3 Blams perfumes at US$20 each; 3 New Blue perfumes at US$25 each and 3 Courd perfumes at US$25 each.

Translated from Spanish by Sally Bolton, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise including perfumes and moisturising cream

loans.name: Rahima

texts.en:
Rahima D. is 43 years old. She is married and has three children. Her family lives in Kanibadam, Northern Tajikistan. Rahima sells clothes for children in the central city market. The location of her vending store is very favorable as it’s in a busy place. Rahima has been in this trade for many years. She has proven to be an honest and communicative businesswoman. Rahima is hoping to make a loan of $ 1200 USD to increase the variety of inventory in her store and keep her business running successfully. She promises to fulfill the loan term within 9 months. This purchase will enable her to increase her sales, to earn more, and to meet the education expenses of her children.


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC.  And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics.  The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy.  In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable.  These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia.  While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increase the working capital to develop the business.

loans.name: Tusaidiane Group

texts.en:
Pili is 29 years old, and married. She also takes care of another family member in her home. Pili has operated her own small restaurant and has also sold clothing in the local Mikunguni neighborhood for the past four years. She earns a monthly profit of around $175, by working daily for fourteen hours. She is currently requesting a loan to increase her inventory, to expand her store and explore the possibility of opening a new one. She is hoping that through this loan, she can boost her profits and save enough money for future use.

Pili will also share this loan with her fellow group members, Asia, Zukelkha, Zuwena, and Khadija. Each of these women owns their own small business in Zanzibar.

loans.use: To increase her inventory and to open a new shop.

loans.name: Soeurn

texts.en: Mrs. Soeurn U. is a farmer in Trapaing Knol village in Takeo province. She owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Her husband, Mr. Am Ann, owns a small business that sells sugar and firewood. In his business, he has a difficult time because he does not have a motorbike to transport his goods. In order to solve this problem, Mrs. Soeurn U. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike for her husband’s business. She is 30 years old and the mother of four children who are attending the local school. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband’s business

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina sells cooked foods and drinks. She started this business in 2004. She hopes for the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell. She is 40 years old and married with 3 children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Vu Thi

texts.en:
Lịch Vũ, 50, lives in the town of Hưng yên. She is widowed and has two adult children. To make a living, Lịch owns and operates a business raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising cattle for sale. Lịch has been engaged in this business for over 30 years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.

In 1997, Lịch joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lịch has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund, used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. Lịch is now requesting a new loan of 15000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell. The loan will be her 10th from TYM Fund. Lịch plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: Purchase livestock.

loans.name: Elda Karina

texts.es:
Elda Karina es casada, tiene 32 años de edad y 2 hijos pequeños, los dos asisten a la escuela primaria, su esposo es vendedor ambulante y le ayuda con los gastos de su casa.  Su negocio es una tienda de productos básicos y además tiene una tortillería a la cual le puso el nombre de “Tonny”.
El préstamo lo necesita para invertir un poco más en sus negocios, ella quiere invertir en la compra de más alimentos como arroz, frijoles, aceite y otros.
Su sueño es incrementar su negocio, tener mayores ingresos, y sacar adelante a sus dos hijos.
texts.en:
Elda Karina is married, 32 years old, and has 2 small children who are in elementary school. Her husband is a traveling salesman and he helps cover the household bills. Her business is a market of basic proucts and she also has a tortilla shop that she named "Tonny". She needs this loan in order to invest in her business endeavors. She would like to invest in the purchase of items such as rice, beans, oil, and more. Her dream is to grow her business, earn more money, and move forward with her two children.

Translated from Spanish by Brittany Thatcher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in merchandise for her market and tortilla shop

loans.name: Marleny Agustina

texts.es:
La señora Marleny Agustina V. M., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Cruz de Motupe II” vive en la Av. las Américas  S/n en la ciudad de Huaraz, en el Departamento de Ancash, tiene 30 años de edad, es conviviente y tiene 04 hijos, 03 de ellos aún dependen de ella. Una de las dificultades de su vida que ella manifiesta es el problema de alcoholismo por el que atraviesa su actual pareja lo que le hace tomar las riendas de su futuro y el de sus hijos.
Con el primer crédito de s/. 300.00 compró pizarras y así se inició su negocio. Tiene 15 años dedicándose este negocio, y es socia del Banco Comunal desde hace 2 años.
Actualmente continúa con el mismo negocio, siempre vendiendo en la Av. Luzuriaga frente al Banco de la Nación en Huaraz.
Con el crédito de S/. 1,700.00 comprará más pizarras debido a la época de campaña escolar. 
Hoy en día se siente mucho más independiente y segura ya que gracias a su negocio es capaz de educar a sus hijos y dar a sus clientes una muy buena atención.
Marleny manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer en su negocio y como mujer.
texts.en:
Marleny Agustina V. M. belongs to the "Cruz de Motupe II" community bank. She lives on Las Americas Avenue in Huaraz city, which is in the Ancash department. She is 30-years old, has a live-in partner, and four children. Three of her children are dependent. One hardship that she mentions is that her partner struggles with alcoholism, which is what has made her take control of her future and that of her children. With her first loan of 300 PEN, Marleny bought whiteboards and began her business. She has had her business for 15 years, and has been a member of her community bank for two years. Currently, she still runs the business, selling her products on Luzuriaga Avenue across from Banco de la Nación (a bank) in Huaraz. With this loan of 1,700 PEN, she will buy more whiteboards, since the school year just started. Today, Marleny feels much more independent and sure; thanks to her business she is able to raise her children and provide her customers with good service. Marleny appreciates the Manuela Ramos program for allowing her to grow as an entrepreneur and a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of blackboards

loans.name: Saiyora

texts.en:
I. Saiyora is 35 years old and lives with her 3 children and her husband. She has a few plots of land which she inherited from her father. For 3 years, together with her husband, she has grown potatoes, onions and tomatoes, which grow well in the local conditions of this zone.

Saiyora leaves very early in the morning to work on the crops and sometimes gets help from her 3 children, too, after they attend school. Now she needs your support and has applied to IMON International for a loan of 1500 Somoni that she will spend for purchasing necessary supplies for her crops.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Angelica

texts.es:
Angelica es socia del Banco Comunal Las Entusiastas.
Angelica es soltera, tiene 21 años y 2 hijos, Angélica tiene juegos de playstation en su casa, juegos que alquila por horas, su negocio esta cerda de un colegio, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Angelica necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en el mantenimiento de los equipos.
Los sueños de Angelica son comprar mas juegos y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Angelica is a member of ‘Las Entusiastas’ Community Bank. She is single, 21 years old, and has two children. In her home she has PlayStations that she rents out by the hour—she does this every day. Angelica needs a 1000 sole loan so that she can keep the games properly maintained. Her dream is to buy more games, and to provide her children with a good education.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For PlayStation maintenance

loans.name: Son

texts.en: Sơn Thị Tạ was born in 1975(female). (010117060014). She lives in Đản Dị village with her husband and 2 children. She washes bicycles and motorbikes and sells soft drinks from her home. Sơn has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,000 VND a month from these activities. Sơn is a lender of a 5-member group loan offered by SEDA. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent, or defaults. She is now requesting a loan of 5.014.000 VND (or 280 USD) to be used to invest in her bike and motor wash store.

loans.use: To invest in her bike and motor wash store.

loans.name: Angel Danilo

texts.es:
Ángel es un joven de 25 años que vive con sus padres en la zona de Pósope Alto, en el distrito de Pátapo, ubicado a 40 minutos de la provincia de Chiclayo – Perú.

Se dedica al servicio de transporte de carga y pasajeros en su mototaxi, esta actividad la viene realizando hace un año y es su única fuente de ingreso, además  Angel es el único que solventa los gastos de su hogar debido a la avanzada edad de sus padres.

El joven Ángel está solicitando un financiamiento de 800 Nuevos Soles, debido a que su unidad móvil presenta algunos desperfectos mecánicos y el dinero que gana no le alcanza para cubrir los gastos de reparación necesarios que garanticen que su moto funcione de manera eficiente y así seguir ayudando a sus padres sin problemas.
texts.en:
Ángel is a young man, 25 years old, who lives with his parents in the Pósope Alto neighborhood, in the Pátapo district, located 40 minutes from the province of Chiclayo, Peru. He transports cargo and passengers in his motorcycle taxi. He has been doing this work for one year and it’s his only source of income. Furthermore, Ángel is the only one who provides support to his household because his parents are elderly. Ángel is requesting a loan of 800 PEN because his motorcycle has some mechanical problems. What he earns isn’t enough to cover the costs of the necessary repairs that will guarantee that his motorcycle will keep working in an efficient manner so that he can continue helping his parents.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To repair his motorcycle taxi

loans.name: Vicente

texts.es: Vicente tiene 55 años, es padre de 4 hijos, quienes ya son mayores y tienen sus propias familias. Actualmente él vive solo en su casa propia en compañía de sus mascotas. Su actividad principal es la siembra y cultivo de plantas cafetaleras y plátanos, todos los días se levanta a las 5 de la mañana para trabajar tranquilamente sin sofocarse con el sol. En el caso de los plátanos, cada quince días cosecha y se dirige al cercado (lugar donde se realizan las ferias de la ciudad), donde se ubican todos los comerciantes y es muy concurrido, por lo que termina de vender rápidamente. En el caso del café, en las temporadas de cosecha trata de acumular la mayor cantidad de producto y espera a los compradores que ya lo conocen y van a buscarlo, donde romana en mano (instrumento que sirve para pesar), selecciona de 12 en 12 kilos rápidamente acumulando el saco de 60, obteniendo un buen precio sin tener que salir a la ciudad, por ello Vicente se siente muy complacido con su trabajo. El es nuevo en MFP y por ello se compromete a pagar puntualmente todas sus cuotas y a participar en todas las actividades de su banco comunal. El dinero que viene solicitando lo piensa invertir en la compra de fertilizantes químicos para sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Vicente is 55 years old and the father of 4 adult children who have their own families. He currently lives alone in the company of his pets. Vicente grows coffee and bananas. Every day he wakes up at 5am and quietly goes about working without suffocating in the sun.

He harvests bananas every two weeks and sells them at different fairs held throughout the city. He is popular among the other traders, so he ends up selling his products fairly quickly.

During the coffee harvest season, it is best to accumulate as much product as possible and wait for the buyers who already know what they want. Using the “romana en mano” (an instrument used for weighing) he rapidly measures out 12 kilos of coffee beans at a time until he has enough to fill a 60 kilo sack. He usually receives a good price without having to leave the city, so Vicente is very pleased with his efforts.

Vicente is a new client of MFP and therefore has agreed to make his payments on time and participate in all Communal Bank activities. The money he is requesting will be used to purchase chemical fertilizers for his crops.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Muneer

texts.en:
Muneer operates a grocery store in his neighborhood.He is 58 years old and a father of four kids who are currently in school.He sells products like rice,canned foods and drinks,candies,evaporated milk, etc. 
The money he is asking for will be invested in buying more merchandise for his store ,in turn,will allow him to provide better services to his customers.He thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: buying more merchandise for his store

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria A. is already 50 years old yet still is an active hog-raiser, a small entrepreneur in their village of San Antonio San Agustin, Isabela. She manages the hog-raising business which serves as their alternative source of income in the village to support their family's daily needs. She wants to achieve success in life, that’s why she is striving to further improve their way of living.

Due to the occurrence of swine disease in their area, Gloria is requesting a loan amounting to PHP 6,000 to buy the medication for her pigs and also to buy enough feed for her pigs. Gloria is hoping that her business may able to surpass the swine problem that is happening in their area because having the business is really of big impact to their survival and to the education of some of her children.

loans.use: additional capital

loans.name: Thoang

texts.en:
Thoang S., 22, is married with a two-year-old child. She resides with her husband (pictured) in Battambong Province, Cambodia. To make a living, she raises ducks at home, earning approximately an income of US $1.50 per day. Her husband is a construction builder who has to travel from place to place in the province, earning an income of US $5 per day.

This young couple is seeking ways to improve their standard of living and to save more money for future household use. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $600 to purchase a motorbike to commute to work. By doing so, S. hopes that she will be able to cut back on public transportation expense and save extra income.

loans.use: buy a motorbike

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine V. is now 45 years old and is happily married to Gaudencio V. who is the same age. The sad part in the married life of Josephine and Gaudencio is that they lost their second child. That’s one of the trials in their life that really tested their faith. So the three children became two: Marites, now 25 years old and working as a sales lady, and Joshua, now 16 years old, and currently studying.

The main source of their income is through their variety store business that Josephine has run for ten years now. When she joined Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), she always used the loans that she received in her variety store business to make it grow. And now with her 8th loan she will use the loan again for improving her business. She will buy necessary things for her business to make it more productive.

As a member of ASHI for four years now, Josephine has been a good member. She is always present at center meetings and always on time in paying her responsibilities. That is why Josephine is really sure that she can make their life a better one because of her effort and with the help of ASHI.

One of Josephine’s dreams is that her youngest son finish his studies because she knows that education is one of the keys to success. She really loves her children, so she always wants the best for them every day of their life. She doesn’t want to experience again losing a child; it really broke her heart so much.

loans.use: To finance her variety store business

loans.name: Sharifa Razya Group

texts.en:
Sharifa is the group leader of Sharifa Razya group. Their are four members in this group. Each would like to receives money for her/his business.  Sharifa is married with six children: four daughters and two sons who are in school.  One boy also works in a video shop. Sharifa wants to take out a loan for another son who works as a mechanic and wants to start his own shop. 

Halema wants to take out a loan to purchase two machines for her embroidery business.  Razya wants to take out a loan for her husband’s general store so that he can buy the necessary materials for his business.  Shaysta wants to take out a loan to expand her tailoring business.

Their requested group loan is for 40,000 Afghani. Thanks to all lenders of Kiva and AFSG in Afghanistan.

loans.use: materials for their businesses

loans.name: Srong

texts.en: Srong S. is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two young children in the Takeo province. Since 1990, she has been selling rice and food to earn a living and is able to make about US$13 in revenue each day. Her husband, pictured here, has a business renting musical equipment to the people who live in the community. On average, he is able to make about US$3 every day. Srong S. is asking for a loan of US$600 which her husband needs to purchase more musical equipment in order to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more musical equipment

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 41 years old and married, with ten children aged between 8 and 26. Her children go to school. Fatuma resides in and rents a two room house where she lives with three people. Fatuma takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and piped water and gets three meals a day.

Fatuma sells bananas in Nalukolongo market seven days a week. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She receives an average of 50 customers a day and sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. Fatuma incurs transportation costs going to and from Mbarara, one of the districts in southern Uganda, to buy bananas. Her greatest monthly expenses include feeding the family, school fees for her children and monthly market dues. Fatuma's major business challenges are seasonality and the rainy season which hinders her customers because she works from a muddy place.

Fatuma has been in this business for ten years and with MCDT for six years, servicing her nineteenth loan. She joined MCDT because it was near her home and was working with poor women. Fatuma wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas. She wants to see her business grow bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Barbara

texts.en: Barbara is forty years old. She is divorced and has no children. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She is a hard-working woman. Barbara is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice with stew. She sells it on a table top by the road side. She also sells ‘banku.’ Barbara buys bags of rice from nearby towns. She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk so she can increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice

loans.name: Gaumati

texts.en:
Gaumati F. is 32 and married with 4 children (ages 9-months - 16 years).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting bananas for sale.  Gaumati has 3 years of experience in this business.  Gaumati needs a loan of WST $750 to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 145 tala or US $60 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Gaumati joined SPBD.  This is her 2nd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Gaumati's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Gaumati F. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                2 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2.63 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.87 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en: Romeo L., is a fish seller in Talibon Bohol. He works everyday to be able to earn an income for his family.  Though he is 60 years-old, he still dreams of prospering in his business so that he will be able to provide for the needs of his children and grandchildren. He started his business in 2003 and he continues to pursue his business because it helps him pay the daily expenses of his household. He would like to apply for a small loan of Php 13,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. in order to buy fishing materials and fish to resell in the town market.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials and fish to resell.

loans.name: Ñepytyvo Group

texts.es:
El comité “Ñepytyvo” se formó con la unión varias vecinas del barrio  Villa La Conquista, de la ciudad de Ñemby. Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas. 

Las integrantes formaron un grupo  muy unido y capaz de realizar actividades en forma conjunta, ya que la mayoría de sus integrantes se dedican a la venta, siendo así la mayoría de ellas, colegas entre si.
Todas las integrantes del comité son madres que se dedican a dichas actividades con el fin de fortalecer la economía de la casa y desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera sustentable.
La Sra. Cayetana R. se dedica a la venta de queso que ella produce a partir de la leche que compra de sus vecinas, pero actualmente recibió muchos pedidos y necesita comprar en gran cantidad para poder abastecer a sus clientes, por ello agradece el préstamos que reciben de la Fundación para llevar a cabo cada sus actividades.
Se citan las actividades de cada una:
1
Cayetana R.
Venta de quesos
2
Sebastian V.
Despensa
3
Maria L N.
Artesana
4
Domiciana S.
Despensa
5
Karina E. C.
Venta de frutas
6
Cornelia V.
Venta de comidas
7
Alejandrina T.
Venta de Ropas
8
Eusebia S.
Venta de Pollo
9
Juana S.
Despensa
10
Maria A. C.
Kiosco
11
Limpia C. O.
Modista
12
Marivel F. M.
Reciclaje
13
Juana G. A.
Artesana
14
Margarita G.
Venta de Ropas
15
Dionicia S.
Modista
texts.en:
The “Ñepytyvo” committee is made up of a group of neighbors from the Villa la Conquista neighborhood from the city of Ñemby. All of the members are working independently in different activities, such as sales. The members form a united and capable group that work together, with the majority working in sales like their colleagues. All of the members are mothers and the goal of their work is to strengthen their household financially and to develop their businesses in a sustainable manner. Mrs. Cayetana R. sells cheese that she produces from the milk that she buys from her neighbors. Currently she has received many orders and has to buy much more so that she can supply her customers. She is thankful to the foundation for the loan that helps her succeed with her work. The work of each one is listed below: 1 Cayetana R. Selling cheese 2 Sebastian V. Selling food 3 Maria L N. Handicrafts 4 Domiciana S. Selling food 5 Karina E. C. Selling fruit 6 Cornelia V. Selling prepared food 7 Alejandrina T. Selling clothing 8 Eusebia S. Selling chicken 9 Juana S. Selling food 10 Maria A. C. Kiosk 11 Limpia C. O. Dressmaking 12 Marivel F. M. Recycling 13 Juana G. A. Handicrafts 14 Margarita G. Selling clothing 15 Dionicia S. Dressmaking

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy milk

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional tomatoes, onions and other commodities

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en:
Ma. Elena Nunez, 44, is married and supports her family through her dressmaking and gown-for-rent business. She lives in Brgy 2, Sipalay City Negros Occidental with her husband, Nonito, who helps her in running the business, and their only child, who is of school age.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000, and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her dressmaking and gown-for-rent business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 13,000.

Ma. Elena Nunez is now borrowing PHP 25,000 that she can use as additional working capital for her dressmaking business. This will be her 16th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Ma. Elena aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Laxmi M. is a grocery store keeper in the village of Thecho. She opened her grocery a few years ago to uplift the economic condition of her family. She sells different types of grocery items in her shop such as rice, maize, biscuits, noodles, snacks, cold drinks, etc. Now, to meet the increasing demands of her customers, she is requesting a 20,000 Nepalese rupee loan to invest in her shop. 

Mrs. Laxmi lives with her husband and two children. Her husband, Mr. Dhana Raj M., is a carpenter. She has one son and one daughter. Both of them are now studying.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Finesse. Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe Finesse sont des femmes mariées  avec une moyenne d’âge de 32ans et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers de la ville de Sikasso (3ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de condiments, d’atiecké tels Sanata Diabaté, de la restauration et de tissus.
Quant à l’utilisation du prêt, Sanata Diabaté compte utiliser le sien pour acheter, 2sacs de 100kg d’atiecké au grand  marché de Sikasso ville et effectue sa vente dans les différents  marchés de Sikasso et dans les quartiers à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes et la plupart au comptant. 
 Tout comme les autres membres du groupe, Sanata envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.250FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée en épargne et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The four members of the Finesse group are married women, and are on average 32 years old with four children. Most of them live in polygamous families in Sanoubougou I, one of several populous neighbourhoods in Sikasso (3rd administrative region of Mali). This is their first collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI, with the purpose of satisfying their customers’ needs. They have different businesses, among which preparing meals for sale or selling clothing fabric, food condiments, or (as in the case of Sanata Diabaté) atiécké, a cassava-based foodstuff. With regard to the loan use, Sanata Diabaté will use her portion to buy two 100-kilo bags of atiécké at the main market in Sikasso. She will then resell it in the various markets of Sikasso and in the neighbourhoods, to a customer base of both men and women, and generally for cash. Like the other group members, Sanata expects an average monthly income of 13,250 FCFA, from which part will be put into savings and the remainder invested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy atiécké

loans.name: Fatima Narcisa

texts.es:
San Vicente es un hermoso cantón de la provincia de Manabí, en el habitan muchas personas dedicadas a la pesca y a otras actividades derivadas de esta, y demás actividades que fortalecen su economía, por su parte la señora Fátima de 48 años de edad, esta desde hace  27 años casada y tiene 3 hijos, Fátima se dedica al comercio ambulante  vende blusas, pantalones, ropa interior, pantalonetas, lleva 20 años con su negocio, y como en muchas familias que a base de trabajo salen adelante su esposo se dedica también a lo mismo,  el recorre cada quince días en San Lorenzo,  un recinto de San Vicente, para su negocio ella invierte cada 15 o 30 días 600 o 1000 dólares depende de la demanda que tenga, sus compras las realiza en la ciudad de Guayaquil, a más de la ropa Fátima también vende sabanas,  ella trabaja también recorriendo por otras sectores donde las prendas que vende son muy apetecibles.

Fátima está solicitando un crédito que de darse, lo piensa invertir en su negocio, ella habla con mucho orgullo que siempre le gusto su trabajo,  ella empezó con 500 sucres dice que le ha ido super bien en su trabajo, y que lo ha hecho gracias  a la Fundación Espoir, por eso está solicitando el nuevo crédito, que le servirá para seguir adelante.
texts.en:
San Vicente is a beautiful county in the Manabí province, where many of the residents dedicate themselves to fishing and other derivatives of this activity, as well as other tasks that strengthen their economy. Fátima is 48 years old, married for 27 years, and has 3 children. Fátima works as a street vendor selling blouses, pants, under garments. She has been in this business for 20 years and, like in many families, they get ahead financially through this endeavor. Her husband is in the same line of business and, every fifteen days, he visits San Lorenzo, a suburb of San Vicente. For her business, she invests $600 or $1000 every 15 or 30 days, depending on demand. She purchases the clothing in the city of Guayaquil. In addition to clothing, Fátima also sells bed sheets and also travels to other areas where her products are well received. Fátima is requesting a loan to invest in her business. She speaks very proudly about how much she enjoys her work, having started it with 500 sucres. She states that business has gone very well, and she has been able to manage thanks to the Fundación Espoir. She is seeking this new loan to continue moving forward with her enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase blouses, pants, shorts, under garments.

loans.name: Renacer Group

texts.es:
Las señoras de este comité son activas, la mayoría de ellas se dedica  a tejer frazadas de lanas, ponchos, y otros ya que es una zona donde se trabaja mucho con este tipo de artesanía.
Todas trabajan y se esfuerzan buscando un poco mas de apoyo para fomentar sus  actividades y de manera ayudar a sus familias.
Necesitan de esta operación crediticia para invertir en sus respectivos trabajos así como la señora Evangelina quien es enfermera y quiere incursionar en la venta de medicamento ya que conoce sobre el tema por su profesión y solicita el préstamos para la compra de medicamento con lo comenzará a trabajar.
texts.en:
The ladies of this committee are active, for a living most of them weave wool blankets, ponchos, and others, as the region is known for this kind of crafts.

They all work and make an effort to look for a little more support to promote their activities and thus help their families.

They need this loan to be invested in their work. For instance, doña Evangelina is a nurse and wishes to start selling medicine as she knows about this because of her profession and requests the loan to buy medicine to start the business.

Translated from Spanish by Lene Struck Christensen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of medicine

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia U. is from the village of Minang Roxas. She is 69 years old. Antonia is married and has 9 adult-aged children. To make a living, Antonia owns and operates a business venture in the food sector, making and selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Antonia has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Antonia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Antonia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,500 PHP from PMPC. Antonia is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizer for her corn. This loan will be the 7th loan taken out by Antonia from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her corn

loans.name: Besiga Mukama Development Group, Mubende

texts.en:
She is 35, enterprisingly ambitious, and a woman with a sense of purpose. She has, for the last ten years, exhibited these hallmarks in operating her retail shop in Mubende Town. She is the mother of three and she goes under the name of N. Justine. Her customers cut across all levels of society, from traders to the lowest common denominators in her locality.

Justine was a nurse before and she used the money she had saved to start this business. She describes herself as a trustworthy individual who customers can put their faith in. This, she says, is the reason why she has lasted this long.

With this loan, Justine says she wants to purchase in bulk retail items that she will resell. This, she says, will lay a good foundation for better profits in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more retail items like basins, cups, sugar, etc.

loans.name: Tomas

texts.es:
Tomas tiene 28 años de edad, reside en el Municipio del Tránsito, Departamento de Usulután, es soltero no tiene hijos, y vive con el papa, la madre y dos hermanos de 17 y 9 años de edad se dedica a la venta de productos de medicina natural.
El negocio lo inicio gracias a la ayuda de un amigo, que también vende productos de medina natura, actualmente maneja solo el negocio no tiene un horario fijo, Tomas esta solicitando un préstamo para mejorar la vivienda, cambiar el techo, con el dinero el quiere comprar Laminas, cuartones de madera, clavos, alambre y otros materiales que son necesarios para el cambio de techo.
El préstamo permitirá mejorar la vivienda de Tomas, darle un lugar seguro donde viva la familia, los sueños de Tomas son tener una vivienda digna para vivir junto a su familia y continuar el negocio.
texts.en:
Tomas is 28 years old and lives in the town of Tránsito in the department of Usulután. He is single and has no children; he lives with his parents and his two brothers, 17 and 9 respectively. He works selling homeopathic medicine. He started his business thanks to help from a friend who also sells natural medicine products. Currently he runs his business alone and does not have a set schedule. Tomas is applying for a loan to improve his home by replacing the roof. He will use the money to purchase roofing materials, wood, nails, wire, and other materials. The loan will allow Tomas to improve his home and give his family a more secure place to live. Tomas' dream is to have proper housing for him and his family and to continue with his business.

Translated from Spanish by Patrick King, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of roofing materials

loans.name: Kuteesa Womens Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
Most people in Uganda have done their utmost through the years to get a settled means of living through subsistence and commercial farming. With this genre of business, it has always been an assured flood tide of financial success whether in the short term or in the long term. Even in the event of drought or famine, many farmers have banked on their reserves to make ends meet. It is therefore surprising to see a person dispense with this kind of lucrative venture. 

45-year-old K. Efulansi decided to go against this grain and made her farming business a subsidiary business 30 years ago. Her deduction was that she would be able to make more profit selling charcoal. She however still maintained her farming business though it now played second fiddle to charcoal sales. With hard work and determination, this married mother of 4 school-going children has achieved her goal. 

In Luleeka, Lugazi where she operates, she has carved out a reliable niche for her business. This explains why her business is still going strong notwithstanding the competition she faces. In a month, she makes profits to the tune of 100,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy more bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Sitha's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consist of twenty-one people who have selected Mrs. Sitha E., aged 49, as their village bank loan president. They are based in Praek Ta Kaev village, Kandal province. The members of this village loan will each use it to support their different purposes.

Mrs. Sitha E. and her husband, Mr. Rorn Buoy, are farmers who own 1.20-hectares that they use to cultivate corn, peanuts and rice for a living. Mrs. Sitha E. will use the loan requested from AMK to buy food to support her family wH. they harvest rice on the farm. This couple works very hard to also support their four children: one is a government worker while the other three are students who also help their parents on the farm.

loans.use: to buy food to support the family when they harvest rice.

loans.name: Savoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Savoeun H. (was in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Chhunnat Khim, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 1994 and have four children -- two sons and two daughters. Three of them are in school and another one stays home. 

Savoeun has been a silk weaver since 1992. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell at Phnom Penh market. Her husband has been a mason for more than fourteen years.

Savoeun is requesting a loan of $800 to build a restroom for family use, and to buy a bicycle for her children to drive to school and to use for her weaving business.

loans.use: To build a restroom for family use, and to buy a bicycle for her children to drive to school and to use for her weaving business.

loans.name: Maria Charito

texts.en:
Maria Charito A. is from Barangay Lantap, Bagabag,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 47 years old. Maria Charito is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Maria Charito owns & operates a business raising livestock, primarily raising pigs for breeding. Maria Charito has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Maria Charito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Maria Charito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Maria Charito is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Maria Charito from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family.
