Paulina dreams to improve her bakery with modern machines and to have her own capital.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fruits, flour and firewood

loans.name: Azalias Flat Group

texts.es:
ESTE GRUPO SE LLAMA AZALIAS YA QUE ES EL NOMBRE QUE LES GUSTO PARA SU GRUPOLA CINCO INTEGRANTES DEL GRUPO Y SUS ACTIVIDADES SON: AMALIA A. C. QUE TIENE UNA TIENDA D. ABARROTES, FRANCIASCA T. Y CRUZ SE DEDICAN A LA VENTA D. PESCADO, MIRIAM VEND. ROPA Y ORLANDA VEND. COMIDA.
AMALIA ES LA REPRESENTANTE DEL GRUPO ES CASADA TIENE 5 HIJOS SE LLAMAN GUADALUPE, JUANCARLOS, LUIS DAVID, MIGUEL ANGEL Y TANIA YULIANA. ELLA QUIERE AGRANDAR MAS SU TIENDA YA QUE  EMPESO A VENDER EN UNA MESITA Y POCO A POCO FUE CRECIENDO Y ESPERA CON  EL TIEMPO CRECER MAS, ESTA SEGURA QUE SU NEGOCIA DA MUCHAS GANANCIAS YA QUE VEND. MUY BIEN Y EL TRATO QUE BRINDA A SUS CLIENTES ES D. LO MEJOR PARA ELLA  Y TODOS SUS VECINOS LE COMPRAN.
CON ESTE CREDITO SE QUIERE SURTIR MAS D. MERCANCIA COMO HUEVO, LECHE, CREMAS, PAN, REFRESCO, SABRITAS, CHILES ENLATADOS, AZUCAR, ETC. SU META EN UN FUTURO ES PODER DARLE  UNA MEJOR CALIDAD D. VIDA A SUS HIJOS  Y SEGUIRLOS APOYANDO EN SUS ESTUDIOS.
DOÑA AMALIA NOS COMENTA QUE LKE GUSTA SU GRUPO POR QUE SE APOYAN Y LE GUSTA LA IDEA  D. TRABAJAR CON FRAC Y KIVA YA QUE EL INTERES ES MUY BAJO Y ELLA SE HA SENTIDO MUY BENEFICIADA Y DA GRACIAS POR AYUDARLA  A QUE SU NEGOCIO SIGA CRECIENDO
texts.en:
This group calls themselves Azalias, because they really like the name. The members of the group and their activities are: Amalia A. C., who has a convenience store. Cruz D. T. Franciasca, who sells fish; Miriam who sells clothing; and Orlando who sells food. Amalia is the representative of the group. She is married and has 5 children: Guadalupe, Juan Carlos, David Luis, Miguel Angel, Tania Yuliana. She wants to enlarge her store and have more things to sell. She started selling from a small table and little by little it grew and she hopes with time to grow even more. She is sure that her business gives good earnings because already she sells a lot. The way she treats her customers is the best and all her neighbors buy from her. With this loan she wants to supply more merchandise such as eggs, milk, cream, bread, refreshments, Sabritas, canned chiles, sugar, etc. Her goal for the future is to be able to give a better quality of life to her children and continue supporting them in their studies. Ms. Amalia tells us that she likes her group because they support her and she likes the idea of working with FRAC and Kiva and because the interest is very low. She feels very blessed and is thankful for the help with her business to continue to growing.

Translated from Spanish by Machelle Wilson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy soap, bread, sabritas, milk, eggs, etc. for inventory.

loans.name: Beatriz

texts.es:
La señora Beatriz P. L., es una señora emprendedora, casada con el Sr. Emilio Claros, tienen 5 hijos, de 16, 14,10, 8 y 6 años de edad, viven en la Comunidad de Londo, ubicado en la provincia de Capinota. 

La señora Beatriz es una señora que se dedica a la lechería, cuenta con 6 cabezas de ganado vacuno, los cuales se encuentran en producción, y de la venta de la producción de leche logra llevar ingresos a su hogar. Su esposo se dedica a la agricultura, en la siembra de zanahoria, cebolla y papa, productos que la señora Beatriz los comercializa en Santivañez. Londo es una localidad que se encuentra a 20 minutos de Santivañez y Santivañez se encuentra a 1 hora de viaje de la ciudad de Cochabamba. Los hijos de Beatriz son niños pequeños los cuales estudian en Santivañez. Su hijo menor tiene problemas de dislexia, que si bien puede ser tratado, no cuentan con los recursos para pagar un tratamiento para este problema, si bien han encontrado a profesionales que les ayuden no podrían pagar este tratamiento entonces han solicitado un crédito para poder incrementar sus ingresos y lograr pagar sus gastos.

Beatriz ha solicitado el crédito para comprar una cabeza de ganado e incrementar sus ingresos, así poder cancelar a especialistas que ayuden a su pequeña hija, si bien no es urgente, pero si necesita que la ayuden a recuperarse.
texts.en:
Beatriz P. L. is an enterprising woman married to Emilio Claros, and together they have five children, ages 16, 14, 10, 8 and 6. They live in the community of Londo, located in the province of Capinota. Beatriz makes a living selling dairy products. She has six heads of cattle to produce the milk, which she sells in order to help the household income. Her husband makes a living in agriculture, harvesting carrots, onion and potatoes, which Beatriz then sells in the town of Santivañez, 20 minutes outside of Londo and an hour from the city of Cochabamba. Beatriz's children go to school in Santivañez. Her youngest son is dyslexic, which can be treated, but they don't have the resources to afford the treatment. While they have found professionals to help their son, they cannot pay for the treatment, which is why they have requested a loan so they increase their income and cover the expenses. Beatrix plans to use the loan to purchase another head of cattle to increase her income. In this way she can pay off the specialists who are helping her young son. While it is not urgent, she needs helps in recovering the expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Albina

texts.en:
Albina C. is from the village of D'Fernan, Bonifacio, Misamis Occidental. She is 58 years old and is single. Albina owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as candies, some food for snacks, sugar, salt, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Albina joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Albina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.  About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Abadacogora Group

texts.fr:
K. Edouard est âgée de 32 ans, il est jeune marié donc il n’a pas encore d’enfants. Edouard est président du  groupe appelle ABADACOGORA, ce groupe travail en commun pour l’expansion de leur business diversifié dont tous font le commerce, il travail six jours la semaine.Edouard lui est vendeur des produit alimentaires qui sont pomme de terre, bananes, haricots.

Edouard et son groupe travail pour augmenter la capacité financière de leur groupe, et valoriser leur business. En fait, le groupe a contracté n prêt au sein d’Amasezerano Community Banking pour acheter les articles pour ravitailler leur business.les bénéfices récoltés après vente de ses produits seront réinvesti pour maintenir la stabilité financière du groupe et épargner afin de préparer pour le bon future, un des mebmres est malade ,c'est pourquoi ils sont cinq sur la photo.

Concernant le groupe
Un prêt de groupe signifie que chaque membre prend son montant et l’utiliser pour son propre business, l’avantage est que le groupe garantisse pour les prêts individuels de chaque membre et si un membre ne parvient pas rembourser, tout les membres du groupe remboursent a sa place.
texts.en:
K. Edouard is 32 years old and recently married, so he does not have any children yet. Edouard is the president of the Abadacogora group, which works together to expand their diversified businesses. He works six days a week. Edouard himself sells food products such as potatoes, bananas, and beans. Edouard and his group are working to increase the financial capacity of their group, and to develop their business. In fact, the group has obtained a loan through Amasezerano Community Banking to buy items to resupply their businesses. The profits gained after the sale of these products will be reinvested to maintain the group's financial stability and savings in order to prepare for a successful future. One of the members is sick, which is why only five appear in the photo. Regarding the group: A group loan means that each member takes a certain amount and uses it for his/her own business. The advantage is that the group guarantees the individual loans of its members, and if one member is unable to repay the loan, all the other group members will make up the difference instead.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy beans. potatoes, maize flour, etc. for retail commerce

loans.name: Zoila

texts.es:
Doña Zoila se dedica a la venta de tortillas se levanta todos los dias a las cuatro y media de la mañana para elaborar sus tortillas ya que desde muy temprano es visitada por sus clientes, vende en su casa de habitacion y tambien sale a vender a diferentes colonias cercanas a su hogar, sale caminando y las vende de casa en casa ya que tiene sus clientes fijos que les vende a la hora del almuerzo.
dependen de ella sus dos hijas de 8 y 13 años las cuales tambien le ayudan a entrgar el producto.
el credito lo utilizara para comprar mas materiales para la fabricacion de las tortillas.

Su esposo trabaja en otro departamento cercano a Tegucigalpa, el trabaja en la agricultura en el Departamento de Olancho y viene cada 15 dias a visitarla a ella y a sus hijas.
texts.en:
Doña Zoila sell tortillas for a living. She gets up at 4:30am everyday to make her tortillas since her customers come very early. She sells them from her home and also, she walks to the different neighborhoods near her home selling door to door because she has regular customers that she sells to at lunch time. She has two dependent daughters, ages 8 and 13, that help her deliver her product. She will use the loan to buy more materials for the production of tortillas. Her husband works in another department near Tegucigalpa. He works in agriculture in the department of Olancho and comes every 15 days to visit her and their children.

Translated from Spanish by Ann Achilli, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase corn flour, wood, lime, water and matches

loans.name: Ramon Daniel

texts.es:
Don Ramon de 38 años de edad es casado, vive junto a su familia compuesta por su esposa y sus 4 hijos en la Comarca Piedra Pintada.  Desde hace 25 años se dedica a la explotacion ganadera y a la agricultura (siembra de trigo, frijol y maiz), ademas se dedica a la construccion y carpinteria dentro y fuera de la zona para asi obtener ingresos adicionales para el sustento familiar.   

Esta solicitando su 1er credito con el objetivo de comprar terneros de desarrollo y fortalecer su inventario ganadero.  

El mayor sueño de Ramon es poder consolidar su inventario para poder brindarle a su familia las condiciones necesarias del hogar.
texts.en:
Ramon is 38 years old and married. He lives with his family, who are his wife and 4 children, in the Piedra Pintada region. For 25 years, he has worked in livestock-breeding and agriculture (sowing wheat, beans and maize), and has also worked in construction and carpentry in the area and elsewhere. This allows him to earn extra income to support his family. He is requesting his first loan in order to buy young beef cows and strengthen his cattle inventory. Ramon's biggest dream is to make his inventory stronger to be able to offer his family the necessary household conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Stansfield, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy young beef cows

loans.name: Linda Urania

texts.es: La señora Linda Urania G. es comerciante y se dedica al negocio  de abarrotes en su propio local donde vende dichos abarrotes. Ella tiene  dos  años de dedicarse a este negocio y se esfuerza por mejorar las condiciones de sutienda de abarrotes. Con el crédito comprará los productos para continuar ofertandolos en la tienda de abarrotes y así satisfacer a todos sus clientes que le visitan para la compra de dichos productos.
texts.en:
Linda is a businesswoman who works selling grocery items. She has worked in this business which is a store operating out of her home for two years. She has had ten loans from CEPRODEL and has used all of them to expand her merchandise and improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Anna Ruby Waxham Blackwell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise such as basic grains and for expanding the business

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie Q., age 48, and her husband have eight children, five of whom are in school. The couple work hard to cover their daily expenses and provide for their children's education.  For the past ten years Melanie has owned and run a sari-sari store (general store) and small salon providing manicures, pedicures, and massages.  

Melanie has requested a PHP 10,000 loan to purchase snacks and other groceries for her sari-sari store in hopes that the additional inventory will help attract more customers and increase her sales.  Loans allow her to buy in bulk, minimizing transportation costs. 

Melanie has been a member of the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) for several loan cycles and has consistently attended weekly fellowship meetings.*  She hopes that eventually proceeds from her store will allow her to fully cover her children's educational expenses. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with no children. She has been operating her retail shop for the last two years. She sells both in a shop and as retail to her neighbors and passers-by.

With the Kshs 80,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase maize flour, soap detergents, rice and kitchen utensils. She earns additional income from her pharmacy shop. Transport is a major challenge for her business. She hopes to make more profit and expand her business in the future.

She decided to join Yehu to get a loan to expand her business. She rents a house with electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

loans.use: To purchase maize flour, rice, kitchen utensils and soap detergents

loans.name: Yos

texts.en:
Yos Y. is married and resides with her husband and two children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for palm products. Y. and her husband are farmers. They grow rice for the family's use. The two children are employed at a local garment factory, earning an income of about USD 5 each per day to help cover the family's expenses. 

The family has to spend USD 78 on food and USD 7 on electricity supply every month. Y. is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase a plot of land in the village to expand her house. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to run a business of selling groceries in front of her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land in the village.

loans.name: Kenia

texts.es:
Kenia es una de nuestras microempresarias se dedica a la venta de alimentos comestible, de consumo diario para la elaboracion de las comidas, es una pequeña tienda a la cual, en Republica Dominicana es llamada Colmado y vive en la ciudad de San Pedro de Macoris, una ciudad famosa por sus jugadores de pelota y por la industria azucarera, su economía actual depende de la Zona franca, la industria del cemento y otras actividades menores como el turismo. Está asociada de Esperanza comenzó con nosotros porque tenía la necesidad de invertir en su negocio.

Kenia está muy emocionada de recibir su cinco préstamo en Esperanza Internacional, después de haber pagado satisfactoriamente sus préstamos anteriores y haber dado un paso para el crecimiento de su negocio. Ella ha tenido su negocio por alrededor de 1 años, el cual inició con un pequeño capital que fue ahorrando mientras realizaba otros tipo de negocio. Kenia está planificando invertir su nuevo préstamo en la compra de Sacos de Arroz, azucar, harina, habichuelas, entre otros alimentos. Ella va a utilizar sus ganancias para reinvertir en su negocio, le gusta leer y su reto mas dificil ha sido estudiar. Su más grande sueño es poder convertirse en una profesional.
texts.en:
Kenia operates one of our small businesses.  She has a store--called a "colmado" in the Dominican Republic--where she sells the common food items that her customers need to make their daily meals.  It's a small store in the city of San Pedro de Macoris where she lives.  The city is famous for its sugar industry and the soccer balls that are made here.  The economy depends on a free trade zone, the cement industry and other activities such as tourism.  Kenia came to us because she needed to invest in her business.

Kenia is really excited to receive this, her fifth Esperanza Internacional loan, after having successfully repaid past loans and making great strides in growing her business.  She started the business a year ago with money that she managed to save while working at another business.  She plans to use this new loan to buy sacks of rice, sugar, flour and beans, among other things.  She will reinvest her earnings in the business.  Kenia likes to read and her most difficult challenge has been to go to school.  She would like to make herself over for a professional career.

loans.use: Buy supplies for food business.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine N. lives in the Mulago neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 3 children, two of whom are in school.  She lives in a home that she rents, and has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees. 

Christine has been in the tailoring business for 2 years, and she works 7 days a week. She has a retail shop in Mulago market. She also generates additional income by selling fried ground nuts and popcorn. Her main business challenge is transportation.  

Christine has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more clothing materials.  Her goal for her business is to improve her standard of living by owning an electric sewing machine.

loans.use: to buy more clothing materials

loans.name: Somos Un Complemento Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “Somos un complemento” es conformado por 22 socias, pertenecientes a la ciudad de Puerto Varas. Sus principales negocios son la venta de ropa, frutas y verduras; producción de mermeladas y frutas en conservas; tejidos en telar y servicios de peluquería, terapias y masajes estéticos.  
Verónica, quien en la foto se encuentra en última fila, en 1º lugar de izquierda a derecha y tiene el pelo corto, se dedica al servicio de manicure y pedicure hace 4 años. Este rubro lo aprendió sola y obtuvo un certificado a través de un curso que tomó por Internet. Con este préstamo comprará los materiales que le faltan para seguir con la construcción de una sala para atender a sus clientes en su casa, ubicada en el patio trasero. También atiende a domicilio. Verónica estima terminar su sala el próximo año. 
Su sueño es crecer en su negocio y mantenerlo en su casa para estar más cerca de sus dos hijas, de 11 y 4 años y cuidar de ellas, ya que el negocio es el principal sustento económico de su familia. 
A Verónica le ha servido mucho el apoyo económico de Fondo Esperanza y también disfruta mucho al compartir con sus compañeras ya que todas comparten el  sueño de surgir.
Puerto Varas es una comuna ubicada al sur de Chile, en la región de Los Lagos, a orillas del Lago Llanquihue. La ciudad se ha destacado siempre por su relación con el turismo, ofreciendo hermosos paisajes naturales, buena comida, playas, parques naturales. También  es conocida como “la ciudad de las rosas”, por la profusión de rosales plantados en sus calles.
texts.en:
The communal bank “Somos un complemento” (We Are the Complement) is made up of 22 members from the city of Puerto Varas.  Their main businesses are the sale of clothing, fruit, and vegetables; production of jams and fruit preserves; weavings, services like hair-dressing, massage, and beauty therapies.  Verónica, who is in the last row, first on the left, with short hair in the photo, has worked giving manicure and pedicure services for the last four years.  She learned this skill by herself and obtained a certificate through a course she took on-line.  With this loan she will buy the materials that she is lacking to continue with the construction of a room to attend to her customers in her house which will be located in the back patio.  She also does house calls.  Verónica estimates that she will finish her room in the next year.
Her dream is to grow her business and keep it in her house so that she can be closer to her two daughters who are 11 and four-years-old so that she can take care of them, as her business is the main source of income for the family.  The economic support from “Fondo Esperanza” (Hope Fund) has helped Verónica greatly and she also enjoys sharing with her fellow members as all share the same dream to grow.
Puerto Varas is a community located in the south of Chile, in the Los Lagos region on the banks of the Llanquihue Lake.  The city has always been known for its tourism, offering beautiful natural landscapes, good food, beaches, and nature parks.  Also, it is known as the city of the roses because of the many rose plants in the streets.

loans.use: Construction materials needed to build a room.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Mirna

texts.en:
Mirna C. is from the town of Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 55 years old. Mirna married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Mirna owns & operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Mirna has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Mirna joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mirna is requesting a loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Mirna from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy 12 pairs of large hoop earrings, 10 tiger eye rings, 12 animal bracelets, 10 Onyx rings, 12 heart bracelets, 10 anklets and 12 ball chains

loans.name: Ferdinand Njoroge

texts.en:
Ferdinand Njoroge N., 47 years old, is married to Nancy Wairimu and together they have four children aged between 8 and 20. They live in Eldoret. Ferdinand has been selling scrap metal for seven years and earns a monthly income of 30,000 KES from the business.

This will be Ferdinand's sixth loan from KADET LTD. He has been repaying all his other loans well and he plans to use this entire loan to buy scrap metal to add to his stock. With the income he is going to receive, he plans to add more stock so that he can earn even more income. His dream is to raise his family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy scrap metal for resale

loans.name: Léster Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Léster Antonio S. V. trabaja como Guiriza en una empresa de acueductos y alcantarillados, desde hace 1 año.

Es casado de 39 años de edad, con tres personas a su cargo, vive en la ciudad de Managua en el municipio de Managua desde hace 39 años.

Este es el primer crédito con CEPRODEL lo solicita para consumo y compra de materiales de construcción tales como: bloques y piedra cantera.
texts.en:
Léster Antonio S. V. has worked for an aqueduct and sewerage company for the past year.

He is 39 years of age and married with three children. He has lived in the city of Managua in the Managua municipality all his life. 

This is his first loan with CEPRODEL. He will use it to buy consumer goods and building materials such as cement blocks and slate.

loans.use: To purchase consumer goods and building materials

loans.name: Mujeres En Esperanza 1, 2 & 5 Group

texts.es:
Raysa (parada con Blusa azul) es una joven empresaria D. apenas 23 años, una familia conformada por sus padres y algunos D. su hermanos. En una vivienda  propia construida en una estructura simple, techada D. zinc y paredes D. block. Sus planes son seguir esforzándose mientras trabaja desea terminar sus estudios universitarios y así poder formar una familia y ayudar a sus padres en sus necesidades. 

Raysa se dedica a L. venta D. calzados nuevos, en compras al por mayor y por catálogos, lleva ya varios años realizando diferentes negocios, y con L. venta D. zapatos lleva ya 1 año, al mismo pudo invertirle su primer préstamo con Esperanza, en L. actualidad recibe su 2 prestamos. Se siente muy agradecida por que con los préstamos a podido avanzar y poder invertir en su negocio. Este nuevo préstamo será invertido en L. compra D. mercancías al por mayor. 

Raysa pertenece al grupo Mujeres en Esperanza 1, 2 & 5, un grupo formado por 15 miembros, cada uno D. ellos días a días realizan sus actividades D. negocios en L. ciudad D. Santo Domingo, en una D. las comunidades D. mas escasos recursos ubicada al norte D. L. ciudad. Su historia representa a los demás miembros D. su grupo y a los clientes D. Esperanza, tanto los haitianos (quienes en su mayoría ha emigrado hacia L. República Dominicana desD. Haití, algunos D. ellos recientemente) y los dominicanos, quienes por lo general viven en comunidades muy pobres, esta zona, como muchas otras zonas D. escasos recursos en L. República Dominicana, carecen D. agua potable y energía eléctrica constante.
texts.en:
Raysa (standing in the blue blouse), just 23 years old, is a young businesswoman.  Her family is comprised of her parents and some of her siblings.  Her own house is built as a simple structure with a zinc roof and block walls.  Her plans are to continue putting forth great effort while she works.  She wishes to finish her university studies.  That way she will be able to start a family and help her parents with their necessities.

Raysa sells new footwear. Purchases are wholesale and by catalog.  She has been in different businesses for several years.  She has been selling shoes for one year.  She used her first loan from Esperanza to invest in her business.  She is currently receiving her second loan.  She is very grateful for the loans because she has been able to advance and invest in her business.  She will use her new loan to buy merchandise wholesale.

Raysa belongs to the Mujeres en Esperanza (Hopeful Women) 1, 2, & 5 Group.  The group is comprised of 15 members.  Each one of them works day to day in their business activities in Santo Domingo.  It is one of the communities with scant resources located to the north of the city.


Her story represent the other members of her group.  Her story also represents Esperanza’s other clients, the Haitians (most of whom have immigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti, some of them recently) as much as the Dominicans. They generally live in very poor communities.  This zone, like a lot of other zones with scarce resources in the Dominican Republic, lacks potable water and steady electricity.

loans.use: To buy footwear
